share.description: create invite link/code for developer preview (allows someone else to create their own account)

apps:apply.description: deploy your application to a chosen color
examples: dog deploy blue
dog deploy blue --force
dog deploy green --path ./custom/script.js

args.name: color
args.description: the backend color to deploy to

apps:build.description: build your application from a template script
examples:
$ dog apps:build

# Use a non-default path to your config
dog apps:build --pathToConfig ./dog-app-config.json

# Or with flag character
dog apps:build -p ./dog-app-config.json

apps:init.description: initalize an app in this directory (should be the root of your project)

apps:list.description: list all apps in your account

apps:rollback.description: rollback a color to a prior deployment
examples:
$ dog apps:rollback blue

# Force rollback a backend receiving production traffic
$ dog apps:rollback blue --force

apps:sharedataset.description: share your BigQuery dataset with an email address associated with a Google Cloud Account
examples: $ dog apps:sharedataset sarah.smith@example.com

cms:preview.description: generate a preview link to a chosen domain
examples:
$ dog cms:preview http://localhost:3000

$ dog cms:preview https://www.example.com

args.name: url
args.description: must be a fully qualified domain name

domains:add.description: attach a CNAME to your application
examples:
$ dog domains:add www.example.com

# Validate your domain automatically (default)
$ dog domains:add www.example.com --validation http

# Validate your domain by placing an extra CNAME with auth code
$ dog domains:add www.example.com --validation cname

# Validate your domain by receiving an email sent to your WHOIS contacts
$ dog domains:add www.example.com --validation email

validation.name: validation
validation.description: specify the validation method - http happens inline, email will send to the WHOIS contacts, cname will return a record that needs to be placed

domains:list.description: list all custom hostnames associated with your app

domains:status.description: check the status of a custom hostname
examples: $ dog domains:status www.example.com

$ dog logs:assetLoadTime
{"asset":"https://example.com/build/main.js","color":"green","duration":85,"protocol":"h2","rid":"abc-567","vid":"abc-123"}

# Filter by asset
$ dog logs:assetLoadTime --asset https://example.com/build/main.js

# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:assetLoadTime --prettyjson
{
  "asset": "https://example.com/build/main.js",
  "color": "green",
  "duration": 85,
  "protocol": "h2",
  "rid": "abc-567",
  "vid": "abc-123"
}

logs:caughtError.description: errors your application caught & chose to log
examples:
$ dog logs:caughtError

# Filter by backend color
$ dog logs:caughtError --color blue

# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:caughtError --prettyjson

$ dog logs:clientPing

# Filter by backend color
$ dog logs:clientPing --color blue

# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:clientPing --prettyjson

$ dog logs:error
  
# Filter by backend color
$ dog logs:error --color blue
  
# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:error --prettyjson

logs:fps.description: instances of client side frames per second dropping below 50 fps
examples:
$ dog logs:fps
    
# Filter by backend color
$ dog logs:fps --color blue
    
# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:fps --prettyjson

logs:longTasksTiming.description: instances of client side tasks that exceed 50ms using the browsers Long Tasks API
examples:
$ dog logs:longTasksTiming
      
# Filter by backend color
$ dog logs:longTasksTiming --color blue

# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:longTasksTiming --prettyjson

logs:mouseDistance.description: euclidean mouse distance, over 3 second intervals, from your applications
examples:
$ dog logs:mouseDistance
      
# Filter by a single request Id
$ dog logs:mouseDistance --rid abc-123
      
# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:mouseDistance --prettyjson

rid.name: rid
rid.description: filter by a single rid (get it from server or proxy logs)

examples:
$ dog logs:orientationChange
      
# Filter by a single request Id
$ dog logs:orientationChange --rid abc-123
      
# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:orientationChange --prettyjson

rid.name: rid
rid.description: filter by a single rid (get it from server or proxy logs)

logs:outcome.description: custom implemented outcomes from your application
examples:
$ dog logs:outcome
        
# Filter by custom outcome (outcomes defined by user)
$ dog logs:outcome --outcome cartAddItem
$ dog logs:outcome --outcome heroImageClick
$ dog logs:outcome --outcome searchAddFilter

        
# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:outcome --prettyjson

$ dog logs:pageScrolling
        
# Filter by pathname
$ dog logs:pageScrolling --pathname /about-us
        
# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:pageScrolling --prettyjson

$ dog logs:pageView
        
# Filter by pathname
$ dog logs:pageView --pathname /about-us
        
# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:pageView --prettyjson

logs:performanceTiming.description: application performance from the navigation timing api including timeToFirstByte, FCP, & TTI
examples:
$ dog logs:performanceTiming
          
# Filter by property
$ dog logs:performanceTiming --property timeToFetchStart
$ dog logs:performanceTiming --property dnsLookupTime
$ dog logs:performanceTiming --property timeToFistByte
$ dog logs:performanceTiming --property timeToHtmlPage
$ dog logs:performanceTiming --property domInteractive
$ dog logs:performanceTiming --property pageLoadTime
$ dog logs:performanceTiming --property firstContentfulPaint
$ dog logs:performanceTiming --property firstPaint
$ dog logs:performanceTiming --property firstInputDelay
$ dog logs:performanceTiming --property tti


# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:performanceTiming --prettyjson

$ dog logs:proxyLogs
          
# Filter by country
$ dog logs:proxyLogs --country US
          
# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:proxyLogs --prettyjson

country.name: country
country.description: filter proxy logs by a single country code (such as US)

logs:rapidClicking.description: incidences of "rapid/rage clicking" in your application
examples:
$ dog logs:rapidClicking

# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:rapidClicking --prettyjson

$ dog logs:serverLogs
          
# Filter by color
$ dog logs:serverLogs --color green
          
# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:serverLogs --prettyjson

logs:timeOnPage.description: time on page activity events (event values are not cumulative)
examples:
$ dog logs:timeOnPage
            
# Filter by pathname
$ dog logs:timeOnPage --pathname /about-us
            
# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:timeOnPage --prettyjson

logs:timeOnSite.description: time on site activity events (event values are not cumulative)
examples:
$ dog logs:timeOnSite
              
# Filter by visibility
$ dog logs:timeOnSite --visibility hidden
              
# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:timeOnSite --prettyjson

$ dog logs:variationInViewport
          
# Filter by featureId
$ dog logs:variationInViewport --featureId abc-123
          
# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:variationInViewport --prettyjson

$ dog logs:variationMousedown
          
# Filter by featureId
$ dog logs:variationMousedown --featureId abc-123
          
# Pretty print JSON
$ dog logs:variationMousedown --prettyjson

proxy:abtest.description: deploy a/b/n tests across any number of origins
examples:
# A/B test between your blue and green backends
$ dog proxy:abtest --origin blue --origin green

# A/B test between your blue backend and example.com
$ dog proxy:abtest --origin blue --origin https://www.example.com

# A/B test between 3 origins
$ dog proxy:abtest -o blue -o green -o https://www.example.com

# A/B test between 4 origins
$ dog proxy:abtest -o blue -o green -o https://www.example.com -o https://www.digitaloptgroup.com

origin.name: origin
origin.description: FQDN for an A/B test backend or a valid deployed color

examples:
# Send 20% of your traffic to your green backend as a canary
$ dog proxy:canary --production blue --canary green --weight 20

# Increase to 50% of your traffic to your green backend
$ dog proxy:canary -p blue -c green -w 50

# Increase to 75% of your traffic to your green backend
$ dog proxy:canary -p blue -c green -w 75

# Force reassignment of all visitors on both backends (advanced - not recommended)
$ dog proxy:canary -p blue -c green -w 50 --reassign

# Decrease traffic allocated to canary backend (advanced - not recommended)
$ dog proxy:canary -p blue -c green -w 5 --force

production.name: production
production.description: FQDN for production backend or a valid deployed color

canary.name: canary
canary.description: FQDN for an canary backend or a valid deployed color

weight.name: weight
weight.description: an integer between 1 and 100 that will equal the percentage of traffic sent to the canary

reassign.name: reassign
reassign.description: forces a new salt to be created and all currently assigned visitors to be reallocated to a random backend - not recommended

force.name: force
force.description: force the proxy config to do something that it not recommended

proxy:gatekeep.description: create a gatekeeping url to any given origin
examples:
$ dog proxy:gatekeep blue

# Gatekeep and open preview mode of the CMS
$ dog proxy:gatekeep blue --cmsPreview

# Gatekeep to any FQDN on the internet
$ dog proxy:gatekeep https://www.example.com

args.name: origin
args.description: a valid deployed color or a fully qualified domain name

proxy:localhost.description: (experimental) create a gatekeeping url that tunnels to your local development server
examples:
$ dog proxy:localhost

# Tunnel to a custom port (default 3000)
$ dog proxy:localhost 3001

# Include preview mode of the CMS
$ dog proxy:localhost 3001 --cmsPreview

args.name: port
args.description: the port of your local server

proxy:prod.description: set your local proxy config to a single production backend
examples:
$ dog proxy:prod blue

# Set any FQDN as the production backend
$ dog proxy:prod https://www.example.com

args.name: productionBackend
args.description: a valid deployed color or a fully qualified domain name to set as your single production backend

proxy:refresh.description: refresh your local config from production environment

proxy:rollback.description: rollback proxy to a prior deployment

proxy:show.description: show current local & deployed proxy configs
